comments:
Marketing 110 is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are to provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions and social policy decision-making, and to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research. 

Students for the most part enjoyed this course. They praised the course materials and said that the information stimulated “strong discussions.” One student described the course as “lively.” Most felt that they learned a great deal from the course and that by the end of the semester they had a strong understanding of consumer psychology. 

Students overwhelmingly praised Professor Cutright. Several students described her with words like “approachable,” “laidback,” “fabulous,” and “thoughtful.” Several students wrote that Professor Cutright had been one of the best professors that they had ever had. One student wrote that Professor Cutright is “engaging and she gets to know the students.” 

Regarding audience, the course is valuable to anyone with an interest in marketing or psychology. In terms of workload, students commented that Professor Cutright put a lot of “emphasis on participation.” Students also mentioned that the final at the end of the course was dense, and it was easy to feel overwhelmed. In general, students wrote that the cases were interesting and worth examination. MKTG 101 is the prerequisite for this course.
